issue.title: Trailing space in ssh configuration file

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
Hi,

I've run into an issue in Fabric that appears to be caused by the way Paramiko parses SSH configuration files (such as /home/$USER/.ssh/config). In [paramiko.config.SSHConfig.parse](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/master/paramiko/config.py#L60) it looks like only trailing newlines (`\r\n`) are stripped. This means that any errant trailing spaces in an SSH configuration file cause issues. An example of a line that would cause an issue is below. Note that the `_` in the file name below would be a space in the real file.

```
Host *.dev.example.com
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/my-dev-key_
```

In the case of a file like the above, an attempt would be made to read the key out of the file '/home/someuser/.ssh/my-dev-key ', which doesn't exist. 

I consulted the man page referenced in `config.py` (`man ssh_config`) and couldn't find any mention of trailing spaces one way or another. However, the OpenSSH client appears to strip any [trailing whitespace](https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/readconf.c#L794).

Would you accept a PR to change `line.rstrip('\r\n').lstrip()` to `line.strip()` in `paramiko.config.SSHConfig.parse`?

Thanks!

body:
Thought I saw a recent patch about trailing whitespace, can't find it but still looking.

Did find #375 which implies we _did_ want this behavior but there's no actual rationale listed... 

EDIT: yea, there's a test that #375 was just making sure didn't get accidentally broken: https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/ade0c259ee1ad630a53998c77ce1d852e417aa50/tests/test_util.py#L113 - walking down the blame on that line leads me back to 02e81785104d97e0634e5a41e87f3b083ea0e952 ca 2006 by robey, which clearly means it's been "intended" behavior since the beginning of the codebase or near enough.

May dig farther in case there is rationale but usually code that old doesn't have a solid reason in the commit message. I honestly can't think of many reasons why trailing whitespace is something anybody wants, and as per #653's investigation, OpenSSH itself performs trailing whitespace stripping.

Pondering whether we should be super careful re: backwards compat, and fix this in the upcoming 2.0 release. But my gut says it's probably hurting many more people than it could possibly be helping, so maybe treating as a regular bug is the right approach.

Yea I can't find the patch I was remembering so I'm probably crazy or it was posted to another tracker. @56quarters if you want to draft a PR as follows, I'd merge it:
- Based on 1.13 branch, not master!
- Updates the existing test re: preserved trailing whitespace to prove that it _removes_ trailing whitespace instead
- Makes sure the `\r\n` stuff still has tests & isn't broken (though I'm assuming `.strip()` would remove it as both chars are whitespace...). tho I dunno when that would even show up, might be a sign of codebase age heh.
Thanks for the guidance @bitprophet, I'll probably come up with a PR this weekend.

issue.title: Update SSHConfig.parse to strip leading and trailing whitespace

repository.name: paramiko
repository.description: The leading native Python SSHv2 protocol library.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

issue.body:
Fixes #499 

Based on 1.13 branch.
- Modified the relevant tests (`test_2_parse_config` and `test_3_host_config`) to make sure spaces and newlines were stripped.
- The existing test `test_13_config_dos_crlf_succeeds` ensures that `\r\n` is still handled correctly

repository.name: fabric
repository.description: Simple, Pythonic remote execution and deployment.

issue.title: trailing whitespace in ssh user leads to bad ssh connection

repository.name: fabric
repository.description: Simple, Pythonic remote execution and deployment.

issue.body:
This is similar to #305 and #619, which relate to the ssh host, whereas this relates to ssh user.
# Summary:

A trailing space in the ssh user will be passed on to the ssh connection process, leading to a failed connection attempt.  This is true for trailing spaces in the User value for a host in .ssh/config, leading to the confusing situation in which `ssh example.com` connects properly, but `fab mytask -H example.com` fails.
# To reproduce

ssh-agent is running with my key for the remote server, as you'll see in the results of the `ssh` command below.

```
$ cat fabfile
from fabric.api import *
env.use_ssh_config = True

@task
def test_fab():
    run('pwd')
$ cat ~/.ssh/config
Host mie
  Hostname A.B.C.D # redacted IP address
  # note the trailing whitespace on the next line:
  User allen 
$ ssh mie
Last login: Thu Jun 25 14:38:13 2015 from W.X.Y.Z
allen@mie:~$ exit
logout
Connection to A.B.C.D closed.
$ fab test_fab -H mie
[mie] Executing task 'test_fab'
[mie] run: pwd
[mie] Passphrase for private key: 
```

If I remove the trailing space from the User value in .ssh/config, there's no problem connecting with fabric:

```
$ cat ~/.ssh/config
Host mie
  Hostname A.B.C.D # redacted IP address
  # No more trailing whitespace on the next line:
  User allen
$ ssh mie
Last login: Thu Jun 25 14:38:13 2015 from W.X.Y.Z
allen@mie:~$ exit
logout
Connection to A.B.C.D closed.
$ fab test_fab -H mie
[mie] Executing task 'test_fab'
[mie] run: pwd
[mie] out: /home/allen
[mie] out: 


Done.
```

I also tried adding `env.user = "allen"` to fabfile.py, allowing for a successful connection. But changing that to `env.user = "allen "` results in the same type of failure shown above. 

Perhaps adding a trailing space inside the quotations when setting env.user is "asking for trouble" in that it should be fairly obvious and will also fail consistently.  Trailing spaces in .ssh/config, however, are not as obvious and will also not fail when connecting directly with `ssh`.
